todos.title: Human Error Myth
todos.body: When something fails, it means that it was not designed properly.

todos.title: Anti Affordance
todos.body: The prevention of interaction.

todos.title: Subconscious v. Conscious
todos.body: Subconscious is fast, automatic, multiple resources, conscious is slow, controlled, limited resources.

todos.title: Short Term Memory
todos.body: Limited to five to seven items.

todos.title: Discoverability
todos.body: Is it possible to figure out what actions are possible and how to perform them.

todos.title: Understanding
todos.body: How is the product supposed to be used?

todos.title: Hidden
todos.body: Hide all critical components that are not necessary for user.  The ideal product should have one button.

todos.title: Poka-Yoke
todos.body: Error proofing.  Devices to constrain operations so they are done correctly.

todos.title: Good Enough
todos.body: Don't strive for perfection in every single aspect of the design and be willing to settle for good enough.

todos.title: Paper
todos.body: Always draw it first on paper.

todos.title: Testing Environment
todos.body: You don't test a real shotgun playing buck hunter.  Test your product in a fully developed environment that best matches the user's situation.

todos.title: Focus
todos.body: You can have a broad customers segment or a broad product feature/user experience but not both (Ex  Anyone can use Google but it has a very narrow product feature/simple user experience, Not everyone can use Microsoft Excel but it has a much broader product features/more advanced user experience)

todos.title: Five Whys
todos.body: When searching for the reason to a problem ask why it happened, then asked why that happened four more times.  When do you stop the blame?

todos.title: Drill Down
todos.body: When people go to a bookstore to buy a drill, that is not their real goal.  Perhaps they want to install shelves so why not discover their true goal and design shelves that don't require a drill.

todos.title: Random Objects
todos.body: Think of random objects and try to find ways to apply them to your product.

todos.title: Mistake Error
todos.body: The wrong goal or wrong plan is established.

todos.title: Mapping
todos.body: The relationship between the elements of two sets of things.  Mapping helps mimic a product to help the user understand how to interact with the product.  An example is the placing the switches for a stove top in the same order and position to mimic the burners that they operate.

todos.title: Different
todos.body: The attempt to match competition is what makes all products the same.  Focus on your users ('customer obsessed'), and throw off the competition.

todos.title: Semantics
todos.body: Study of meaning.

todos.title: Feedback
todos.body: Some way of letting you know that the system is working on your request.  Remember that too much feedback (dishwasher beeping at 3am) can be annoying.

todos.title: Sleep Rehearsal
todos.body: Sleep helps us rehearse things in our head.

todos.title: Feedforward
todos.body: Signifiers, constraints and mapping that help indicate what a user can do with the product.

todos.title: Wizard of Oz
todos.body: Set a customer up in a room to interact with your software.  Have them ask it questions and instead of having the computer respond, have a person in the other room pretend to be the computer and respond.  This will help teach you a lot about your user experience.

todos.title: Affordance ('is for')
todos.body: Relationship between a physical object and a person.  A chair affords (is for) sitting.  If the chair weighs 300 lbs it does not afford lifting or moving.  Affordance is a relationship, not a property.

todos.title: Accepting Multiple Formats
todos.body: Programs should be able to treat 1/5/15, Jan. 1, 2015 and 01-05-15 as the same.

todos.title: Instructions Not Needed
todos.body: Products should be simple and simple products do not need instructions.

todos.title: Legacy Problem
todos.body: Products are designed poorly because of outdated standards.

todos.title: Lock-In
todos.body: Prevents a a person from prematurely stopping an operation.  An example is keeping the program running until it is finished saving.

todos.title: Lockouts
todos.body: Preventing and action until something has been done.  Example password protected site.

todos.title: Expectations
todos.body: Play and important role in our emotional lives.

todos.title: Forcing Function
todos.body: Physical constraint that forces the user to do something so that they cannot fail.  An example is forcing a driver to push down the brake before you can shift gears.

todos.title: Slip Error
todos.body: Person intends to do one action but ends up doing something else.

todos.title: Learned Helplessness
todos.body: People experience repeated failures at a task so they assume it cannot be done.  Reason you should eliminate error message from programs and instead provide a process to help user.

todos.title: Purchaser v. User
todos.body: Often the purchaser is not the user and you must design so that both parties understand.

todos.title: Design Thinking
todos.body: Never solve the problem you are asked to solve.  The problem you are asked to solve is never the root problem.

todos.title: Checklists
todos.body: Need to cover the essential but not too burdensome to perform.

todos.title: Undo Command
todos.body: Most powerful tool to prevent errors.

todos.title: Thermostat Myth
todos.body: Most people think that if you turn a thermostat on high, it will heat up quicker, most thermostats only have two settings, full blast until temperature is reached, and off.

todos.title: Time Stress
todos.body: Most errors are caused by time stress.

todos.title: Combatting Errors
todos.body: Minimize steps, contrast features, provide reminders, force functions (like removing card before receiving cash).

todos.title: Multiple Faculties
todos.body: Make sure that people from all company divisions are involved in design process.

todos.title: Security Balance
todos.body: Make something too secure and it becomes less secure.  Example, having too many passwords that you must trust them in something insecure or securing the building to much so that people end up propping certain doors with bricks.

todos.title: Waterfall Method
todos.body: Linear and sequential design that is hard to backtrack when decisions have been made.

todos.title: Contrast
todos.body: Like parts cause confusion.  Contrast everything.

todos.title: Keep it Simple
todos.body: Keep it simple.

todos.title: Skeumorphism
todos.body: Incorporating old fashioned and familiar ideas, images, machines, into new technologies.

todos.title: Three Ways to Store Knowledge
todos.body: In the head (brain), in the outside world (journals, hard drives), and via imposing constraints on the world (setting self up for future success).  The most effective way of helping people remember something is to make it unnecessary.

todos.title: Cultural Differences
todos.body: In Arabic and Hebrew time flows from right to left, others use a left to right system.

todos.title: Clues
todos.body: Human mind with a few clues can discover how to do almost anything.

todos.title: Resilience engineering
todos.body: How to help people cope with complexity under pressure.

todos.title: Standards
todos.body: Generally accepted terms and designs to help people carry knowledge and usability from one product to another.

todos.title: Interlock
todos.body: Forces an operation to take place in the correct sequence.

todos.title: Shadowing
todos.body: Follow customers into the shower to identify their real problems.

todos.title: Activity Centered Design
todos.body: Focus on the greater activity, not the individual tasks a person is trying to accomplish.

todos.title: Constraints
todos.body: Features that limit options to help use the product correctly.

todos.title: Featuritis
todos.body: Excessive features.

todos.title: Human Centered Design
todos.body: Designs to accommodate human needs, habits, capabilities, behaviors, and emotions.

todos.title: Swiss Cheese
todos.body: Design redundancies to prevent the law of compounding errors.  Requires you to identify all the possible mistakes that could be made and then install redundancies to make sure that they don't all line up and compound.

todos.title: CRAP
todos.body: Contrast, repetition, alignment, and proximity are fundamental to good design.

todos.title: Mental Models
todos.body: Conceptual models in people's minds.

todos.title: Complexity
todos.body: Complexity is essential, confusion is undesirable.

todos.title: Signifiers
todos.body: Communicate where an action should take place.

todos.title: Jidoka (Japanese)
todos.body: Automation with a human touch.

todos.title: Conceptual Model
todos.body: A highly simplified model of how something works.

todos.title: Storytelling
todos.body: Very persuasive medium.  People are innately disposed to look for causes of events to form explanations.

todos.title: Number Five
todos.body: Five is the ideal number of subjects to study for your test product.
